articles.headline: Fed Official Says She Favors ‘Prudence’ in Raising Interest Rates
articles.snippet: The remarks by Lael Brainard, a proponent of continuing the Fed’s stimulus campaign, reinforce expectations that the Fed won’t raise rates this month.
articles.abstract: The remarks by Lael Brainard, a proponent of continuing the Fed’s stimulus campaign, reinforce expectations that the Fed won’t raise rates this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lael Brainard, a Federal Reserve governor and a leading proponent of the Fed’s efforts to stimulate the economy, said in a speech on Monday that she still favored “prudence” in raising interest rates despite recent signs of economic progress.

articles.headline: Value-Seekers Warm to a $450 Annual Credit Card Fee
articles.snippet: Cards that were once more about elite service are now emphasizing their bottom-line value proposition — even when it comes with a hefty annual fee.
articles.abstract: Cards that were once more about elite service are now emphasizing their bottom-line value proposition — even when it comes with a hefty annual fee.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seldom does a new credit card go viral.

articles.headline: Saudi Bid on a Houston Oil Refinery Is a Big Strategic Bet
articles.snippet: Despite political tensions with the United States, Saudi Arabia sees another American investment as a way to help counter weakness in the oil industry.
articles.abstract: Despite political tensions with the United States, Saudi Arabia sees another American investment as a way to help counter weakness in the oil industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Saudi national oil company is making a bid to significantly expand its operations in the United States at a critical moment in the always uneasy relations between the United States and Saudi Arabia.

articles.headline: Pervasive Sham Deals at Wells Fargo, and No One Noticed?
articles.snippet: The inevitable misbehavior in a case involving 5,300 bank employees creating sham accounts and generating $1.5 million in fees.
articles.abstract: The inevitable misbehavior in a case involving 5,300 bank employees creating sham accounts and generating $1.5 million in fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I don’t want anyone ever offering a product to someone when they don’t know what the benefit is, or the customer doesn’t understand it, or doesn’t want it, or doesn’t need it.”

articles.headline: Pregnant Women Anxious as Florida’s Zika Test Results Take Weeks
articles.snippet: The state offers free tests to pregnant women, but a lack of resources has contributed to a backlog that has left hundreds waiting a long time.
articles.abstract: The state offers free tests to pregnant women, but a lack of resources has contributed to a backlog that has left hundreds waiting a long time.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — So many pregnant women have taken advantage of Florida’s offer of free Zika testing that state laboratories have been unable to keep pace, doctors and patients say, leading to long delays for women anxious to know whether the virus has passed to their fetuses.

articles.headline: IPhone 7 Review: Though Not Perfect, New iPhones Keep Apple’s Promises
articles.snippet: Although they lack a headphone jack, the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus are fast, their cameras take superb photos and the batteries last longer.
articles.abstract: Although they lack a headphone jack, the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus are fast, their cameras take superb photos and the batteries last longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple’s iPhone, just short of 10 years old, has hit puberty.

articles.headline: U.S. Household Income Grew 5.2 Percent in 2015, Breaking Pattern of Stagnation
articles.snippet: The median household’s income last year was $56,500, a significant increase from the previous year, the Census Bureau said.
articles.abstract: The median household’s income last year was $56,500, a significant increase from the previous year, the Census Bureau said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans last year reaped the largest economic gains in nearly a generation as poverty fell, health insurance coverage spread and incomes rose sharply for households on every rung of the economic ladder, ending years of stagnation.
